name: One Finger Death Punch
description: Experience cinematic kung-fu battles in the fastest, most intense brawler the indie world has ever seen! With the unique 1:1 response system of One Finger Death Punch, players will feel the immediate feedback of every bone-crunching hit. Pay tribute to the masters using five classic kung-fu styles mixed with additional weapons.

reviews.review_text: You: I know Kung Fu Game: Show me  ---------------------------------------------------------------  Bought this game on release as a joke. Was not disappointed
REVIEW HAIKU  Stick figure kung-fu  Entrails flung across your screen  Quite mesmerizing

One finger death punch is the ultimate example of a game with bare minimum graphics and controls that manages to work it to its advantage. Your hits have to be lightning fast but at the same time carefully calculated, which makes the impact of your every move immediately demonstrated. Enemies come and go in an almost rhythmical hypnotizing frenzied fashion and it is admirable how the game manages to make your fighting style look almost flamboyant with such little resources at its fingertips. One finger death punch is a must have for people who like beat' em up games as well as for those that don't, since it has a magical ability of drawing you in for just one more level.
Actually its more like two finger death punch
Awesome stick-man fighting game. You control the whole game with only two buttons (Keyboard, Mouse or controller are supported). It sounds easy, but it isn't. Buy it and you will have a lot of fun!

One Finger Death Punch is a refreshing experience in an industry that is saturated with AAA games (well at least the notion of AAA).  The game takes a very simple idea, using very simple controls (just two buttons), builds on it and polishes it to a very fine level. Looking at the video on the Steam page may make you think that you can get through this 'simple' game with button-mashing. However, you're very wrong if you think that way. The game warns you from the very start that button-mashing will get you nowhere. One Finger Death Punch builds on its simple controls to create a gameplay system that gets positively sophisticated.  You will face different enemy types that require different combinations of clicks/keypresses to defeat. While the fundamental gameplay mechanic (left click/arrow to hit left, right click/arrow to hit right) stays the same, the different combinations add up to make up for a fascinating gameplay experience. Let's just put it this way - the moment you think that you've got the game figured out, it throws you a new enemy type, a different level mode that challenge you to sharpen the very skills you thought you've mastered.  There is an RPG element to this game. As you progress through the game, skills become unlocked. These skills add on to your overall gameplay experience and help you manage as the pace of the game gets faster and faster.   One thing that surprised me about this game is how the voice acting (well, if we can refer to the sensei as that) adds to the game. It gives the whole game (each and every stage) some sort of dramatic sense with the sensei explaining to you the game mechanics.  I find myself coming again and again to clear earlier stages, trying to outdo myself each time. I would love to see this game on a handheld (e.g. PlayStation Vita).   I definitely recommend this game. It's amazing how a well-polished gameplay system can bring the fun that we've been seeking (perhaps in the wrong places)

I got this through a bundle and had expected to play this for 5 minutes and be done with it. Instead I ended up playing for 40 minutes, having a blast and actually feel like I had a good grasp of this, especially considering I do not enjoy combo brawlers. The simple controls makes this very easy to get into, and a steady difficulty curve makes you keep progressing. The first couple of boss battles also makes you want to play just one more round as it's never an impossible task to win. Getting into the weapon upgrades is where it really moves from a fun 2 minute distraction into a pretty cool game. The only bad thing is not being able to use the mouse for the menus if you started the game with a joypad, but I'm sure it'll be fixed in a patch.

If someone told me I could log 9 hours of a rhythm game without getting bored, I'd probably laugh at them.  One Finger Death Punch (OFDP) is a simplistic fighting/rhythm game made by Silver Dollar Games, not the most reputable or consistent of studios. It features stickmen engaging in kung-fu, to about 5 different songs, and 5 different backdrops. The 'gimmick,' if you will, of OFDP is that it is played with just two buttons, M1 and M2 (X and B on a controller). Simply put, M1 is left attack and M2 is right attack. Very simple controls.  It is surprising how addictive this game is. With a concept so simple, you would think it would be repetitive, and boring after the novelty of it wears off. The thing is, OFDP manages to use this concept so incredibly  right  that you can just keep going and going and going...  It is responsive as hell. The music is catchy, and while there isn't much of a variety of music, it never seems to matter. The animations are as good as stickmen-kung-fu is going to get. The announcer is the perfect B-list kung-fu announcer. Legitimately the only thing this game can't pull off is the transistion/loading screen. It's horrible.  Hell, there's even a  lightsaber  light-sword round.  For $5 this game might seem like a bit of an expensive gimmick. It's not. For $2.50 this game might seem interesting but repetitive. It's not the latter. For $1.25 you might as well try it.  This game is definitely worth your time, even if you just play it for an hour and see what I'm making such a fuss about.  4/5.
this game is just WOW, its so awesome!!  only $4, a must must buy!!

Deceptively simple to learn, but relatively hard to master, One Finger Death Punch will test the quickness of your reflexes, and the sturdiness of your 2 chosen buttons.   Okay, I'll just play a couple levels to kill some time then...    2 hours later...    One... more... level!
Incredible. It manages to take simple gameplay and take it to a whole new level. Challenging, but you never feel like it's the games fault if you fail. Highly recommended.
If you wish to monetize a game that could just as easily have been a flash game, this is how you do it. Easily worth the price.  Rarely have I had this much fun using just two buttons in a game.
'Fight using only the left and right mouse buttons! When you fight, your cursor can be anywhere on the screen!'  8/10 great stress reliever!

The game is so very simple, yet so very satisfying. The only buttons you use in the entire game are the left and right mouse buttons, but the action is furious and satisfying to witness. As you progress through the game the action gets faster and the types of enemies get more difficult. It's really a fun and challenging test of speed and reflexes.

One Finger Death Punch is the best example of less is more. It did what so many other games tried to do but failed at, and for that One Finger Death Punch is awesome.  There legit are only 2 keys in the whole game, only 2 and thats left and right (or whatever you configured them to be). However, do not be fooled by only 2 keys as the game is quite complex, especially as you get later on. If you mess up your reaction and timing for the different sides with your 2 keys, you may find yourself dead very fast. You basically only have to beat up enemies coming from the left and right along with different variations of that. But the enemies become more and more complex with certain boss like ones too. There are different level types as well, including regular, speed, break objects, etc. Along with the different level types, there are also a plethora of levels available that will keep you frustrated for quite some time later on. The game really does a good job in almost every aspect. The music, narration, progression, and every fits and works very well together. Don't forget that even the price for this game is very reasonable.  I'd recommend this game to anybody. I mean, for a game this cheap and this good, why not get it?  Rating: 8.8/10 Recommend Price: Full Price or any discount
Awesome game. Challenging and fast paced. Over 150 achievements. Easy game to just pick up and play when you only have 5 minutes. Looks like it has a good amount of content too.
Pretty good but a sort of mini-game with lots of fun levels.
Great animation and artwork Runs fine on my potato Great gameplay mechanics Random levels No DLC

I love this game, the concept is so simple yet manages to be so damn fun at the same time. A brawler game at it's purest form. Get this game, it's cheap, fun and has a good amount of content for it's price tag.
Just buy the damn game
Don't judge a book by it's cover.  10/10

This game totally lived up to my expectations.  A game that only uses 2 buttons, has unique graphics and seems repetitive. That is the impression OFDP makes on a number of people. I can tell you straight away to throw that attitude away immediately. This game offers amazing gameplay, very many levels and even multiple gamemodes. I see how some people think it would become repetitive, but this was not the case for me. Because new opponents keep appearing, the game got me eager to beat them. The controls are extremely easy; it's just two buttons. The gameplay is fast and will adjust to your personal skill level. There is no story whatsoever, but that's not what this game's about. I think this game is amazing, offers great gameplay and will definitely keep you busy for quite some hours.

Great simple game, if you like brawlers and kung-fu movies a must buy.  Pros: -very fair and skill based -fluid -great voice acting and music -just feels awesome and makes you feel like a badass martial arts master -various diffrent stages and battle types  Cons: -might get repetitive quite fast if you dont like beating scores -it will destroy your wrist/fingers if played with mouse (havent tried with a controller yet) -might not be worth the full price considering how small, even though well executed it is, definitely worth it from sale/bundle   Recommending it, had a lot of fun playing.

This is the most fun I have had with one/two fingers in my life! Great game, terrifc slow-down modes for the kill shots, lots of excitement (for a game where you do not move)! Defintiely a must own; because who doesn't enjoy giving a good beat down from time to time?
Rip mouse and fingers.. :P I very like that game I even played on it on my mobile phone. Fun and Funny game at same time 10/10 worth buying that
I used one finger to write this review.
It's fun

Simple to play but will take some mastering, I was surprised at how in-depth a combat game like this can be with a simple two-button mechanic but its fluid and highly playable. This game will definitely test your reflexes and get the adrenaline going.  Love some of the small touches you get like the special animations you see now and again like an xray of an enemies bones breaking, throwing an enemy out of the screen or even punching through someones chest and popping their heart out of the back lol.  Well worth the asking price.

This game is amazing. It's very fast paced and the animations are simple yet very stylish. The whole stickman theme is great. The voice-overs are a bit cheesy but not annoying. For a game that only utilizes two buttons, it's not easy, making it a perfect example to show that simple =/= easy.  What I actually want to add to this review is the support. I had some troubles getting this game to work and I've contacted the dev and also posted on the game's forums, here on Steam.  The response from the developers was very fast and kind, also showing me that they're willing to go through a lot of trouble to help.
One of the simplest and most fun games I've played in a while.  Looks laughable at first. Look past that. Check it out.

Who woulda thought that a 2 button game would be good? Unfortunately this one is not good. Its GREAT! From the first hit of the button it was instant addiction and the action get so good at times that you can get lost. This game is all about finness. Meaning if you press a button too many times, not enough times, or not at all, it is game over man! Then throw in some weapons and it becomes coorindated chaos. I've gotta make this review short so that I can get back to playing but even at $4.99 this game is worth every penny. Passing this one on sale is not a good idea. Why you ask? Well if you end up paying full price you'll banging your head against the keyboard for now buying it earlier and when it was cheaper. I'd give this a 9/10 , -1 for the moderately weak graphic design. Otherwise I can not find any reason to not jump on this one.

Two button DDR in which you play a stick figure murdering hundreds of other stick figures.  Has plenty of stages on branching paths throughout the world map, where you can also unlock powerups from beating certain stages.  The game is pretty challenging and also goes against button mashing, making every click count.  10/10 Would implement into every fighting game ever.

WARNING: It is first important to acknowledge that the title is a complete lie; you require not one, but TWO fingers to adaquately perform the 'death punch' on numerous enemies. Utter lies.  Other than this gaping flaw, this game is brillliant. Nothing's more satisfying than watching endless streams of stickmen being disfigured, disembowled and dis...look you just absolutely slaughter them. Various weapons add (a little bit of) variety, all of which your Spartan/Ninja/Samurai badass can use to tear apart enemies as fast as you can click the button of your mouse. Despite only having two controls, the game is fast paced and addicting, with plenty of replayability whenever you have 5 minutes free. Highly recommend.  TL;DR - The most fun you'll ever have with two fingers. Get it.

Sincerely this is one of the best games I have played this year. It's simplicity is it's genius. One Finger Death Punch provides the kind of fast paced and adrenenaline inducing highs of pure gameplay zen that are a hard to find anywhere else. The variety of martial arts that can be reproduced by a simple stickman is astounding and the game has a real charm all of it's own.   An extremely entertaining, satisfying and challenging game that is well worth the asking price.  Play it!

This is my favorite 2 button fighting game and here's my reasons, some legit, some shallow, some might even be a bit nonsensical why:  1. Art style - I know some people hate the whole stick figure thing but I think with the backgrounds and fighting styles and the intense speed at which enemies are coming at you the last thing I'm focused on is what my character looks like. I remember way back when a little flash series by the name of Xiao Xiao. That stick figure series was awesome and if only for nostalgia purposes this game brings back memories.   2. The developers didn't waste time figuring out how the character looks instead they developed what matters most, which is the fighting style so at the end of the day when you're playing a 2 button fighting game you're seeing a lot of fighting variations for a 2 button fighting game.   3. You don't have to button mash or press a series of complex controller commands to do the really fun moves. This happens automatically and I don't get callouses or slight carpal tunnel from twitchy thumb movements.   4. The different environments are incredibly detailed. When I'm fighting in the Light Sword round for the 5th time trying to get a perfect I never get tired of cutting up enemies or seeing the burst of flames around me in the middle of the match. Also to add to that the various skills that you gain throughout the game and the slightly challenging boss battles.   5. The game adjusts attacker speed depending on how well you're doing. So when you start to suck the game will dial back the speed so there's less of those rage quit moments and you can focus on having fun.  There's no cheap story thrown into why you're fighting hoards of guys but you really don't need one. The only down side I can see is that cheezy Asian voice announcing or giving you tips every now and then but that I can ignore because the rest of the game is so good.  I also want to say, I played this game DRM Free for a while before it got its Steam release. And I think if this game is something I'd play without it being on Steam it must be pretty good.

You know those old Newgrounds animations where it's one stickman kicking the crap out of a bunch of other stickmen?  This game is that, except you're controlling the stickman who's doing all the ♥♥♥-kicking.  'Nuff said.
Just 2 clicks they said....just 2 clicks...       DAMN THIS GAME IS EPIC
Extremely useful for practicing your reflex actions

The game helps you to speed up and slow down your mind thru a process of counting and reaction. I'm unhappy with the game, because for it to truly help gamers, they need an option where a person can have full range of the entire screen, and click right and left. While the limited range of attack has it's purpose. It limits player who need intensity training. I'm dissatisfied with the game due to 3 reasons. 1st you can't set the speed of attack manually, even at later levels. 2nd you can't set the range of attack. 3rd. A lot of the items impede speed training instead of promoting it, for instance the weapons take 1 click to pick up, and 2nd click to strike, randomly dropped weapons then become a hindrance, and can cause a miss due to user not clicking twice or miss due to clicking twice. Weapon pickup system needs to be perfected especially since they have 0 tolerance for hit or miss. It's also crazy that you can get hit 4 times and miss 0 and get more reward. Missing an opponent is worse than being hit by one and frustrating when playing. No reward for killing `99 ppl just consequence for missing one guy then killing him again with the second click. The miss system seems to me to be flawed.  'Oh Master Yin punched the air, he loses a point, oh he punched again and killed a man, he gets a point. '  I do realize the sys is in place to prevent spammers, though more distance or double click instead of single click miss allowances are needed. Bare min just allowing a no enemy weapons option would make me happy. Too many random weapon frustrations when playing. I've enjoyed it though it can be more enjoyable with more options. It should be ez for creators to add more fun options if the creators still exist. Either way it’s a fun cheap game.
I punched some stick guys heart through his back in slow motion nuff said.
an amazing waste of time. in an incredibly good way. just get in the zone and destroy 5000 faceless foes.
One Finger Death Punch is a strategic, fun, indie, and very addictive supplying hours of simple two button fun. I recommend this game to anyone looking for an addictive, easy game.
Best $5 on Steam ever.

I have felt it now. I have witnessed the wholeness of life, It's a part of me now. My once dry and bitter soul is filled, I can now live the rest of my days in peace thank you Silver Dollar Games.

This game is one of those, 'Why didn't I have this as a kid?' 'Even better, you have it as an adult!' moments. Reminds me of old Xiao Xiao stick fighting animations and newgrounds games n stuff. Games a ton of fun, at the time of writing this review I'm around 1/3'd through the game. Totally a steal at 5 bucks (or 4 when I got it on sale).

Amazing value for this price, makes you feel like a kung-fu badass. Its easy to get into but hard to master and will keep you playing far longer than you expected.  ♥♥♥♥ will give you carpal tunnel with all the clicking though so be careful.
Game says I can have my cursor anywhere on the screne to play, but when I try to play with it over the level reset button it resets the level. wtf?

One Finger Death Punch is an addictive, fast paced, somewhat silly, smile-inducing homage to kung fu movies. This is what happens if Bruce Lee & Jackie Chan made a Stick Fighter video game. 2D and side scrolling it may be, but this is no a hinderance at all. The gameplay is akin to rhythm matching with one hand, but the action is so much more fun to watch. As I play, I find my smile getting cramped and tired from being there so long. The memories of my misspent youth watching Kung Fu movies on Saturday afternoons comes flooding back with every bone cracking, eye-popping, heart-bursting hit. :D  In short, this is the most fun you can have with one hand and tell your mom about it.
Dont even think, JUST GET THIS GAME!!!
'One fingered death.'

I was given this game as a gift from a friend, and while grateful wasn't expecting much of it - especially when I learnt that the controls were just two buttons. THREE HOURS LATER... I am incredibly impressed by how such a simplistic game concept can be so entertaining. :3  At time of writing it's $5 on Steam (that's if you buy it alone and not in a bundle, or though a different website), and is *easily* worth the price. :-D  It's one of those games that has such good gameplay that words alone will not convey it. (PS: I recommend a gamepad, though it's not required - it is a two-button game, after all.)  Edit: The only flaw I've seen in it so far is that it doesn't update Achievements in real-time. I'd been playing it and figured maybe it didn't have achievements, only to find when I closed the game that all thirty-seven achievements I'd obtained just poured in at once. Not a big deal by any means, but I wasn't expecting to have every achievement I've got so far all have the same timestamp. :-p

The experience with this game was really fun, epic, and gets addictive. What's good about this game is that it's not a game where can you button mash, yet it's only two buttons, but it could get so competitive that you would get confused at some point. The graphics for this game is decent for it's type (it is a stick figure game). I would suggest to get this game if you have money left from your account and dont know what to buy next.

A unique two-button action game! I really enjoyed it; recommended.  Worth playing, even though it might get difficult and/or repetitive at times. But, you can stop playing whenever the speed and difficulty becomes too much, or when your mouse buttons stop functioning! I don't usually play action games, but this one was quite fun for 20-30 minutes every other day.  I finished/cleared all the levels in the 'Student' difficulty (first of three).

Way more fun than a two-button game should be allowed to be! I sat down for a 5 minute test drive and ended up playing for an hour. Addictive gameplay. Awesome. Why aren't you playing this game right now?
Fun as hell
Bishy Bashy Slashy of Awesomeness. Also, Lightsabre Nunchucks! What more could you possibly ask for?
This fast-paced, two button, stick figure game is more fun than you would imagine.  It's definitely worth $5.  Caution: Very addictive. :)
It's awesome but you will need two fingers.
Simple yet very fun. Good grab on sale

Great casual game that has a very simple concept (left and right click) and excellent execution. Higher difficulties start getting rediculous though...
An amazing game you can play for hours on end. It doesnt look and feels like you shouldnt be able to play it for hours and have a great time but you can.
Ridiculous fun. I just lost an hour to 'just one more level'. And did about 20...
Deceptively simple yet hard to master and very addictive little gem of a game.

Surprisingly fun for a seemingly simple game. Ridiculous number of achievements. But the best part is the survival mode where a cat keeps walking onto the screen and you have to shoo him off so you can see behind him.
I don't need to make my father proud because the tutorial master is proud of me already. Just watch me, sensei, I won't let you down!
Already woth th 4$ I spent, Got 4$? recommend.
sticks + combos = stickgasm

I played this game for 20 min. These were the most awesome 20 min of my day! Cannot wait to play more!  You play the game using only left and right mouse button.... but it works perfectly! The game is perfect for letting some steam and anger out as you massacre hundreds of stick-men using awesome kung-fu moves and weapons (there are lightsabers!!!!)  I must say that this game reminded me of childhood days in school when me and my friends were drawing stick-man fights animation on pages of our school books... priceless <3  Great game!
click the left and right mouse buttons feel like a god 10/10 best stickfighting game i've ever played

I came across this game watching a video review of the top ten games of 2014. It looked simple and interesting...and cheap enough to take a gamble. Wow, I'm becoming amazed on how some of the simplist games are just downright extremely fun to play. Who needs some complex story with 100 things to click. Here you have a game that requires you to press two buttons (with on your mouse or a USB controller). That's it. You just focus on the screen and do your best on combating various stick figures. It's not one of those games where you might do a marathon session with. It's one of those games you might have a little time or want something a little different, and have a lot of fun with.  Highly recommend.

Simple and addictive, flashy, smooth, knows what it wants to be, sets out to do it, executes spectacularly. Has just the right amount of polish and lo-finess to be charmingly... EXTREME. ♥♥♥♥'s good, go play it.
10/10 would get carpal tunnel again
Have you ever wanted to punch a heart out, how about chop a face off? Well if you answered yes, hell even if you answered no. It's right here for however much the game may cost.
Actually you use TWO fingers... but still one of the best games I played. Really fast, really fun, makes you feel like god among men. 10/10
Epic sweetness with a challenge
THIS GAME IS AWSOME!!

For those put off by the simplicity of this game, please look past it and give it a shot. Its fun, addicting, and really surprised the hell out of me! I'm mad I didn't get this game sooner! This is a gem thats sure to keep you busy for awhile, especially if you're an achievement hunter

If you want simple, yet addicting brawler, this is a game for you.  This game and it's simple two button game mechanics is very satisfying. This may look very cheap (and it is), but it is an excellent game worth your money. The stickman style of graphics works for this games favour and the effects look very cool when you kill horde of enemies coming to your way. I was very sceptical about this game and now I can't let it down. Also you don't have to invest lots of time for this game. It only takes about 1-2 minutes to beat a level and it doesn't have any annoying tutorials like most of the modern games do. This game is pure gold and I will keep on playing it.
This is some of the most fun I've had with two fingers...I am impressed. My kid is now bugging me for it..Dev plz make a blood splater option

I am surprised how good this game is. You only have to click left or right mouse button, but clicking at the right time can be tricky. Game introduces itself with a hilarious warning 'button mashing will KILL YOU', and it's very true.  It isn't an easy game, and you have to be strategic with weapons you can grab on the level. You also can unlock skills, and while there are a lot of them, only three can be active at the same time; it adds a bit of extra strategy.  There are about six different types of the levels, which prevents game from being repetitive (it's still repetitive, but it's a game of two buttons).

First of all this game is extremely simple and repetitive. That being said i really enjoy playing this game. The concept is simple enough. Enemies come from both sides and once they enter the hit box you take them out. The enemies become stronger taking more than one hit to defeat and gaining the ability to dodge and switch sides. the number of enemies per level also increase. Its a great for a quick 5 minute game session, but i've also spent hours at a time as well. If you're looking for an intense action game that requires minimal effort and maximum enjoyment this is the one.

So I'll be honest,   I had some Steam Credit left over from the holidays and I decided to find the best reviewed games under $10 and I stumbled upon One Finger Death Punch - after looking at the reviews with over 99% approval rating I figured that I'd give the game a shot and for $2.49 if it didn't live up to the expectation it was less than coffee and a bagel.  Absolutely, by far worth the full price of $4.99 if not more. The game is addicting and it's enjoyable, playable for hours and an amazing form of stress relief.  If you don't have this game yet, you need to get it.
It's impossible to play this game without a big grin. Simple, fun and totally addictive. Buy it!

This game is one of those that's super simple yet challenging. I like that in a game. The learning curve is super simple which leaves so much more time for simply enjoying the game. It revives the xiao xiao nostalgia and puts you in the seat of the main character. I love it.

What can I say. This game is AMAZING. The team at Silver Dollar has done what many companies strive for but few have succeeded in. They have made a game of simplicity and pure fun. From the beginning to the end this game delivers.  From the moment you start up the game one thing is very clear. This game has a personality, and that personality is awesome. With an epic soundtrack that would make any Shaw Bros. kung fu movie of old jealous you are emersed in a journey through intense kung fu battles all via your simple stick figure avatar.   The controls are just as simple as the graphics, and there is a beauty in that regards that many big budget games seem to overlook. You don't need fancy GPU instensive graphics to have fun. You just need fun to have fun. From silly death animations to a variety of incredible levels involving light swords, nunchucks, thrunderstorms, and retro film themes you are a kung fu master, and often I found myself just laughing and smiling through countless sessions and levels.  In addition to this fast paced action world of wonder the devs have even taken it one step further by adding numerous levels and game modes for you to enjoy in increasing difficulty. Not only is the game immensely fun, but it's also challenging and hard as you progress. The depth and skill curve is accurately balanced as the game adjusts to your speed of difficulty finding that perfect calibration to your skill level.  There is no doubt that this is a special title. It's not often that you get to experience a game like this, but even in your last moments of hardship in the game the devs are right there sending you a sword from the heavens as if to say 'We know you might not make it, but take this.. we believe in you'. I haven't had this kind of experience playing a game in a long long time. It's nothing but pure joy, and a title I would recommend to anyone looking for a game that is fun, challenging, funny, epic, and that has a lot of heart. (that is unless it gets punched out)  10 out of 10.

I don't know how it's possible, but this team managed to take a simple concept and make it an enjoyable mess of fun and violence. The humor strikes true (No Luca, no!!) and for the price I had to pay this, it's more than a bargain!

One Finger Death Punch  is a game that harkens back to the days of 2D animated stick figure fights like the  Xiao Xiao  series. It's an incredibly fun experience that puts you in control of the main character of one of those flash animations - the number of enemies means nothing, and you tear through them as a nigh-untouchable god of martial arts.  And yet playing as this rampaging deity requires precisely two buttons. There are no complex combinations to memorise, just 'left' or 'right'; based on the situation, you might deflect a spear, throw a bomb or slam someone into a table (breaking the table in the process, obviously). How well you do depends entirely on your timing and reactions.  The game has two main modes.  Survival Mode  has you face an infinite onslaught of enemies until you run out of health, and there are three flavours of this mode to unlock.  Story Mode  consists of a network of short stages that eventually lead to a 'final stage', and has three difficulty levels that affect the game speed and the number of enemies in each stage.   Story Mode  is the more varied of the two (despite its name, there isn't any actual story - feel free to imagine your own). There are a good variety of stages - examples are the Smash Round, which has a quota on objects destroyed rather that opponents killed, and the Multi Round, which is much shorter than the others, but has to be completed several times in a row at increasing speed.  Based on how you perform in Story Mode, the game will speed up or slow down to match your skill, though there is a minimum speed associated with each difficulty level. Clear a stage too easily, and the game will increase its pace on the next one to ensure a challenge. This sort of feedback allows for both the casual and hardcore player to enjoy the game. Failing a stage will make the next attempt a bit easier, and for some, pushing the game to higher and higher multipliers is enjoyment in itself.  Scattered across Story Mode are stages that, once beaten, unlock skills for the player to equip. Skills have a killcount that, once reached, will trigger the activation. The skills, too, are diverse - one causes weapons to drop, allowing you to pick them up and use them, another lets you throw the next weapon you pick up, and a third clears the entire screen of enemies. Crucially, you can equip several skills at once, allowing the player to mix and match skills they feel would work well together (for instance, the first two mentioned). There are some stages where skills are disabled, but most allow them. They are also available for use in Survival Mode (but must be unlocked via Story Mode first).  The only issue that I currently have with the game is that it will occasionally go into slow motion to show a particularly vicious punch, which can throw off your timing somewhat. While I do appreciate that it's done for spectacle (and rightly so), it has cost me a life on several occasions. An option to disable these would be nice.  Apart from that (small and pedantic) matter, I can wholeheartedly recommend picking up  One Finger Death Punch . It's a great game for passing small amounts of time (I get a bit burnt out playing it for too long, your experience may differ), and adjusts well to your skill level. The graphics, simple as they are, do not detract from the gameplay, which is immensely fun, and makes you feel like the most powerful stick figure of them all.

One Finger Death Punch is a rhythm based action game where the player controls a kung fu fighter who is being attacked by a constant stream of enemies from both sides of the screen. You can't move, so your only controls are attack left and attack right. Its a simple concept but it takes skill to master, because if you time an attack incorrectly it will leave you open to being hit. There is no story, so its entirely focused on gameplay.  Some enemies take multiple hits to kill, you can collect weapons which temporarily extend your attack range and there are various skills to unlock which let you use weapons for longer or slow enemies down. However, a large number of levels don't let you use any skills, which is kind of annoying, because those were the levels I had most difficulty in completing, but there is no possibility of changing tactics.  My favourite part of the game is when the ball of death is on the screen. It can one hit kill any enemy, but if you miss the ball it will bounce off screen, so its fun trying to juggle the ball between enemies for as long as possible.  It took me 4 hours to finish the campaign mode, although its possible to do it much quicker. The level select screen confused me for a while, I thought I needed to beat every level, but that's not the case. The path branches at several places and you only need to follow one path, so you can skip alot of levels. You don't really miss anything because most of the levels are pretty much identical. There are also a few variations of an endless mode where you can chase a high score.  Its probably a good thing that the game is short, because I physically couldn't play it for longer than about 60 minutes at a time before my hand/arm started hurting due to the constant clicking. The speed round is a good example - kill 90 enemies in 55 seconds, some enemies take more than 1 hit = probably more than 2 clicks every second. However, the purchase price is extremely low, so its still easily value for money.  I also feel like its almost more enjoyable to watch someone else play the game, because you can enjoy the animations better. I realised after a while that my attention was focused far more on the HUD below my character which tells you which direction to attack and how many times to attack, and I wasn't really watching the action. I couldn't tell you whether my character was kicking, punching or stabbing. This problem is fixed in blind survival mode, which removes most of the HUD, so I wish the whole game was like that.  Ultimately, One Finger Death Punch is a fun time waster that will entertain you for a few days, but I wouldn't say its an essential purchase.

This game has no right being as awesome as it is.   It's an extremely simplified brawler. In fact you only use two buttons to control the entire game. Your character stands in the center of the screen, and to your left and right is shown your characters reach. When an enemy walks into this zone, you click the corresponding mouse button and unleash kung-fu justice. It sounds astoundingly stupid and simple, but the entire experience comes together to make it great.  It's surprisingly skill based, since you can't button mash. Button mashing = Death. Every click corresponds to a move from your character. Most enemies take one hit, some take more, some dodge your attacks and come up on the other side of you. As you play each levels you get a sort of flow going, in fact in many ways it's kind of like a rythym game, but instead of music you are punching to the rhythm of enemies as they approach you. And you're not just punching, you're kicking, shooting bows, throwing knives, breaking bones, splattering eyeballs, tossing bombs, even juggling a spiked ball of death. Just the combat itself varies from the multitude of weapons and enemy types. But then there are special stages with different objectives, bosses, light sabers. The game adjusts itself to your skill level as well, speeding up or slowing down enemies as you complete levels. It's crazy just how much fun this game is. And especially with how affordable it is, there isn't a reason to not get this game.

Deceptively simple controls for such a complex game. There are only two buttons. The game is easy to learn, yet hard to master. You need to keep on your toes and plan your moves carefully if you want to avoid missing (and getting punched in the face afterwards). Button mashing will only get you killed, the game makes this abundantly clear from the start. Every press matters, so you have to focus and make every hit count.  You can immediately tell that the developers went for gameplay over graphics. The graphics aren't much to look at, just a few stick figures (probably animated in Pivot) against a rather generic background. But don't let that stop you from buying this game. There's a reason this is the second highest rated game on Steam. It's unforgiving yet fair, and you will feel like a pretty awesome guy after the first few levels.  Overall, I'd give it a 9 out of 10.

This game is veery easy to recommend.  On first sight, it looks like a cheap throwaway game, but... you're right, it's cheap. Cheap as in 'definitely worth the money, even when it's not on sale'.  The basic premise, in case you still don't know, is to just kung fu like crazy left and right. And that's the only thing you can do -- hit left or hit right. This extremely simple gameplay makes it a very casual game -- anyone can just pick it up and play it.  However, it's not easy to master. by any means. The difficulty ramps up as you progress through the 'campaign' levels or run a survival game, as enemies get faster and you get more enemies requiring multiple hits to kill.  At any time, the game keeps you informed what you need to do: enemies show you the left/right combos required to kill them, adjusting as you actually perform these hits. The game shows you when a hit on the left or right will actually hit something. So again, very casual, not really anything to learn.  However, at the same time the game feel snappy and responsive, and every hit counts. Senseless button mashing won't get you anywhere, you need to hit the button when it counts.  The game might also look simple, but the graphics are actually quite nice. The stickmen are well animated, and you get the occasional special kill-scene which not only provides a closeup view on some bloody mess you are creating, but also gives you a short break before the frenzy continues. And frenzy it is -- there's little time to admire animations or backgrounds as enemies are rushing in left and right.  Adding to this is a speaker giving you the tutorial hints during the early 'campaign' levels -- and again, this isn't just some random guy, they got a very nice dialect one would expect from an american kung fu movie.  There are minor technical details I don't like, such as having a launcher window -- but those are minor. It's hard to find anythng to actually complain about on the gameplay...

This a review of a playthrough of the entire game on the easy difficulty and the first two out of three survival modes.  There is not really much to this game aside from being awesome. You click with your left or right mousebutton and you attack left or right, that's the entire game. It is a lot more interesting than it sounds though, because not only is it already hard as hell using only two buttons, but there a a lot of modes throughout the campaign that bring a lot of variation. There is rounds where you fight huge waves of enemies, rounds that get faster and faster, boss rounds, rounds with a nunchuck or a lightsword permanently equipped and more. There is also a bunch of skills to be gotten that kind of let you individualise your playstyle. I have to say though, these skills are what kept me sidetracking, as soon as I had them all I had no interest in completing all levels and just wanted to get to the end. This is why I do not reccomend to play this game in to long play-sessions, it just loses its fun at some point. Also: while this seems like the standard internet flashgame with stick figures it is not. the combat is actually rather complex and the campaign is a lengthy one. All in all it is a definitive thumb up for those who lick stick man fighting, those who like challenging games with simple controls and those that think that the screenshots and trailers look awesome enough but are worried the game wont hold up.

A little game with pretty cool graphics, awesome soundtrack and sfx and a surprisingly intensive feeling.   The concept is simple: Left mouse button moves/punches/kicks/blocks/counter-strikes/picks up a weapon on the left side of your awesome warrior stick figure, and the right mouse button does the same to the right side of your avatar. All the while mooks are streaming in from both your left and right side and most of the time is to out-survive the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.  Sure, the battles get a bit repetitive after a while, but in small amounts I keep on coming back to this game. Kudos to the developers for managing to get as many battle modes out of a simple two-button game as they have. Make no mistake though, in it's core this is a two-button reaction game in its core. But oh boy have they managed to make it interesting!  The audiovisual feel of the game fits perfectly into the theme of old martial arts movies and the combat animation is really fluid and enjoyable to watch - when you're not too focused to miss them while trying to time your actions just right.

This game is immensely satisfying...You'd think that, with just two buttons, the game would be boring, right? You wouldn't be more wrong. This game does a lot with just two buttons. You can impale dudes on weapons, kick bouncy spiked balls across the screen, and get into rapid-fire melee clashes against the 'brawler' enemies. However, this game is pretty strict about timing: you cannot button mash or mistime an attack, or you will be punished. You must time your attacks properly in order to survive...Once you get the hang of the system, it's very enjoyable to see dudes get their faces smashed in. You also earn skills that you can change between levels, and you earn medals for completing the level with no misses/no damage. Yes, they are separate, and you'll be thankful for that--trying to perfect each level is tricky, and I'm not even out of the first difficulty yet!  The art style is very striking: at first it looks like a kung-fu flick, but the characters are actually all stick figures. If you've ever watched Xiao Xiao's stick figure animations, you'll probably know what to expect. I don't mind the art style being 'simplistic' or 'low budget' at all, this becomes a nonissue once the level begins and you're punching dudes into fruit carts. The music is also appropriate, sounding like something you'd hear out of a Jackie Chan or Bruce Lee flick. The music really gets your blood pumping and into that 'zone' where, despite all the craziness going on, you're one with the game and feel like you can do anything.  That being said...My biggest criticism against this game is the sensory overload it brings. Aside from all the enemies charging in, there are super attacks that occur randomly, combat notifications that appear as you rack up more combos, and the skills that activate once you meet certain requirements. It can be a little overwhelming, especially as the game speeds up. Thankfully, the game's speed is adjustable: if you die on a level, the game speed is reduced greatly. That being said, even at ~120% speed, the game can reach that point where it's too fast to even think about what you're doing, or try to do. I have lost many perfect runs because of misreading what was going on--the game really penalizes you when you miss, and it really teaches you be controlled in your button presses.   Another criticism I have is the lack of video options: I play in a window most of the time, and it's juuuust big enough to go beyond the edges of my monitor, and shrinking the game sizes changes the play area but not the window size. I wish there were different resolution settings we could pick from, or be able to resize the window manually.  Quirks aside, this game is probably the best five bucks (halve that if you got this during the Summer Sale) you'll ever spend. It's over the top and flashy without being some big-budget beat'em up like Metal Gear Rising, yet it has easy to understand controls and some satisfying mechanics. You haven't lived until you get into a light sa--excuse me, light sword fight, carve up a ton of dudes while explosions erupt in the background, then you get onto a slow-motion duel against a miniboss before finishing him off and seeing that huge 'PERFECT' appear onscreen. Long story short, buy this game if you enjoy the zany combat or want something new in your beat 'em up library. You won't regret it.

It's hard to assign ONE FINGER DEATH PUNCH to any genre but it's easy to say that this game is a masterpiece. It doesn't shine in art-design, story or presentation but it's the best of it's kind in the gameplay department. In ONE FINGER DEATH PUNCH you only have 2 buttons: the left and the right mouse button. This game has more gameplay with just 2 buttons than most of the AAA titles have. You play a white stickman that has to battle it out with tons of other colored stickmen. He can punch left and he can punch rigtht. Nothing more nothing less. Your foes begin to charge you and you hit them with your fists. That's the gameplay in a nutshell. But there are tons of mechanics that make this type of gameplay interesting and not tedious at all. You can pick up weapons, use skills, throw bombs, and you can do tons of other stuff that help you out. Additionally there are foes that dodge your attacks or need multiple hits to die. Those mechanics make the game feel more fun and challanging. There are even bonus rounds that keep the game fresh. And again all that with only 2 buttons. Everybody who says that this game has not much to offer don't understand the fundamentals of gamedesign or haven't played long enough to understand this wonderful game. This is one of the best games I've ever played in rescent time and the best 5bucks I've spend in my whole life. Go get this beauty.

I love this stupidly simple game. Two ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed buttons. How could this ever be fun? It's fun because it's as close to boiling down beat-em-ups down as Divekick did for fighting games. Not quite that level of distillation, but pretty close.  You get perks by beating levels, and the first difficulty available is alright. The game ramps itself up on Master, though, and the various blind modes test your reflexes like nobody's business. Normally you have colored bars under the enemies that tell you the button you have to push for each point of health. Blind mode you only have the color of the enemy (patterns vary by enemy color.) And then there's color-blind blind mode...no colors, no HP bars.   Put on some hype music for best effect. Priced well for what you get, great for fast-paced, bite-sized action. Only complaint is the relatively limited amount of fighting styles (really just determines your animations).

This game is the ultimate proof that it's not about how many fancy bells and whistles you have, it's about how you use what you've got.  It's got a very straightforward control scheme, but it manages to leverage two buttons into something more challenging than you'd ever expect. It hits a pretty damn perfect balance in difficulty; it's hard without being overwhelming, and the difficulty adjusts to your skill level as you play, though it never goes below a certain point. Of course, it doesn't hurt that when it clicks, the game makes you look and feel like an absolute badass in a way no other game I can remember has done, so that in and of itself is incentive to keep playing and get better.  The game assets are full of stick figures, generic images, bad accents, and royalty-free music, but that simplicity actually works for the game, rather than against it. If assets were more complex, it wouldn't be as easy to keep track of everything once the pace accelerates to lightning speed, and the brief animations help to emphasize the brutality and precision of the characters' movements. The game announcer can get a bit irritating at times, but if it really starts getting on your nerves, there's always an option to turn it off (at the main menu...).  If you absolutely can't stand fast-paced games, this won't change your mind, but otherwise, the low barrier of entry means you have very few reasons not to give One Finger Death Punch a shot.

One Finger Death Punch is a fighting game that only uses two butons (so I guess you need two figners to death punch). There is no movement -- left click attacks foes to the left, right click attacks foes to the right. The controls are simple but it can get fairly complex beacuse some enemies can dodge your attacks (by switching to ther other side) and it can be difficult to get a rhythm.   Of course, the gameplay is repetitive but I thought this game was fun. There are a few different modes, like one where you use nunchucks to kill cannon fodder enemies and then fight a boss at the end. My favorite is the speed round where you have to kill enemies as fast as possible.   Overall, One Finger Death Punch is a fun fighting game with simple controls.

I do enjoy this game for the pure joy of the zen-like attitude you have to take during so many of the missions. There are so few games that distill gaming down to a zen-twitch mentality (Robotron is my ideal zen-like game). HOWEVER, a big difficulty can be the idea of color recognition. As a semi-color blind person, some of these color-oriented enemies can be difficult to figure out. Nevertheless overall, I've had fun!

I know there's already a ton of reviews of this game, but I just had to add another positive one.   This is one of the most fun games I've played in a while, even including big AAA big budget games. It has just enough charm and addicting game play that 'one more level' turns into a 2 hour session.  It's amazing how such a simple premise can work so well, and be challenging at the same time. The difficulty builds at a steady pace, and the variety in levels keeps it from getting stale. I can see myself keeping this installed in my library at all times, and picking it up when I just want a break from other heavy games and just want to have a blast!  For something this cheap, it's worth every penny and then some. I'd highly recommend this game to anyone considering buying it (and even those that aren't!).  10/10 (especially for the value!)

This game is ridiculously addicting. The concept is so simple and the graphics are stickmen. But I can't stop playing.  The basic concept of the game is that you control your character with two buttons (right and left mouse buttons). Enemies attack you and you have to click on the corresponding side to beat them. There are two modes - levels and survival. Levels is sort of like a campaign mode, where you complete different missions (kill a certain number of enemies, boss fights, timed levels, etc.) to unlock skills. These skills can then be used in the survival mode. Survival mode you try to last as long as possible.  There are three difficulty levels for each mode. For levels you have student, master and grandmaster. You unlock one by beating the prior. For survival, you have to get to 500 kills in the previous mode. Survival is a bit more interesting. The three difficulty levels are survival, blind survival and no luca no. Survival is the normal mode. Blind survival takes away all life/hit indicators on the enemies and you have to go by memory or reaction to defeat them. No luca no is a special mode that I won't spoil =].  All in all, for $2.49 (holiday sale) this game was well worth my time. I'm still enjoying it and its addicting to try to get better scores on each level.

Speechless...  Only kidding but seriously, I don't normally do fighting brawlers like this but it is a blast.  Two buttons, three rules:  1) When an enemy is in range you move to hit them with left or right mouse. 2) If an enemy gets too close they hit you and knock out 1 life 3) If you attack when no enemy is in range you MISS which also briefly leaves you open to attack (so no button mashing)  You start with 1 HP enemies but then they slowly build up enemy variants until you're juggling a massive onslaught.  I'm having a hard time explaining the deep strategy...  OK here's an example: the range is not close quarters you can't move normally but when you attack you close the distance... so do you wait for them to get close to line up a series of blows or do you close and attack so that you get away from an enemy you don't want to tackle?  Here's another: later on you run into enemies that take the first hit and dodge to the opposite side of you... do you continue to attack the dodged enemy or do you attack the enemy that WAS behind him.  What starts as a simple 3 rule 2 button game becomes a deep, tactical brawler, where due to its nature you feel like you're achieving from the word go, winning by mashing is one thing, beating by skill is another.

Two things come to mind when I play this.  1. how addictive or compelling very simple games can be 2. how bad my reaction time can be ((or maybe it's how prone I am to button mashing)  When I was younger I really quite enjoyed the flash animations from the bunnykill series and this game reminds me a lot of those but with a more human protagonist. Weapons can be picked up and used for a while but once the level starts it doesnt stop so most of the gameplay is indeed punching.  The action itself is something I find I tend to miss on the more frenetic levels as the eyes tunnel vision onto the bars that indicate left or right. Thankfully there are breaks while the game gives a slomo kill animation as you slice the face off an enemy or impale them on a discarded spear.  Other things to add to the game are levels where you can only use a set weapon like nunchaku or throwing daggers or a visual change like a sepia/b&w old movie look. I'm avoiding monotony as a word as you could easily say that describes the game but with the variation of levels and a good selection of unlockable skills this does a very good job of being anything but monotonous.  And as far as levels go, there are a lot on the map screen and then you realise you can zoom the map out to see more, then zoom again to see even more.  Unless you're playing survival then each level is quite short which makes this a very good option as a filler game as well as one you could sit down and slaughter your way through for an hour or so.  Well worth the £4

This game... One FInger Death Punch, Is awesome. I got it really cheap on Steam for like 2 dollars or something? (Thats US, btw.) and it is worth every penny. I've spent more time in this then I have on some of my more expensive games.   One Finger Death Punch is incredibly simple at the core. Your a stick figure kung-fu dude who is faced against waves of other stick figures coming from both sides, you have to fight them off by clicking one of two mouse buttons depending on the side there on.  Sound simple right? Well it is, but that doesn't mean its easy. Because the game pentalizes you for missing, and even 1 miss drops from platinum to gold. So you have to be careful. No button mashing in this game!  There are also different enemies who take multiple hits and the such, as well as several different types of modes in the 'adventure' type mode, which has quite a few levels.  It also includes different skills to mix things up as well.   Overall its really just a lot of fun, and very addicting to try and get the best score and not miss. And definately has challange to it. As well as achivements to go along with it, giving all the more incentive to go after a good score.  Oh and it includes a leaderboard to.  Overall this game is very addictive and fun, I totally recommend it, even at full price, its the best 2 dollars I think i've spent on a game.

I found this game through Markiplier on youtube. I thought 'Sure looks fun. I'll give it a shot.' Now I'm hooked.  This game is so simple but that is what makes it great. You don't have to worry about managing items and the skills are simple toggle on/off unlockables that you hunt down as you progress across the map. There's no level system to worry about. All you really need to focus on in this game is what is coming at you and where from.   As you progress you'll come across more complex enemy types and modes. Enemies will begin to dodge your attacks and game modes will offer new challenges. Skills are awesome and simple. You can equip three at any time and you get them by completing certain levels that are marked with the image of the skill they reward. There's my favorite, the deep impact skill which allows you to wipe out all the enemies on screen with a single blow after a certain amount of kills. There are skills that allow you to use weapons for longer than normal periods of time, which is great because weapons increase your range of attack slightly. There are skills that give you extra throwables when you pick one up, throwables are insta kills on any enemy. and there are plenty of other skills that when you put together properly, can really give you an edge.  You have to be careful though. If you play too aggresively you can miss a striker which will leave you open. It gets difficult not to get into this game especially if you have your favorite music playing in the background. But the key is to take care and watch what is coming at you. If you take your time you can get somewhat strategic and deal with tougher enemies faster.  For only five dollars this game is a steal and if you like a challenge the higher difficulties will scratch that itch.

Extremely addictive and original, yet simple game. Remember those youtube stickman fights? Now you can participate in one those. Your stickman fights against hundreds of enemies coming from left and right. You will use different kung-fu styles, sword, spear, staff, bow, mace, nunchakes...even LIGHTSABER! Lots of levels, stages, enemies. Difficulty scales with your skill.  This game is not about button-mashing, it is about skills and timing. A must try for kung-fu fans.

Can't recall when I've last wanted to get better in a game more than I have in this one. The levels are very inspired and you just feel like a total badass when blasting through enemies without a single misclick. And the game rewards you for it with awesome slowmo sequences, skill procs and the hysterically stereotypical announcer. Plus the sheer impact on your attacks is spot on.  Don't get me wrong, the game isn't void of challenge either. I'm halfway the lowest difficulty and at this point can't imagine what the next 2 difficulties have in store. There's tons of content and loads of replayability to get those platinum medals and no-damage tags.   It's a good game to hop on in short bursts for a quick 'damn I'm awesome' -feeling. And it really delivers that feeling the more you play.

This game is so great on many levels. It's simple yet complex as you have to instanly figure out how to maximize your attacks to kill the maximum amount of enemies in a single chain. Strategy, timing, patience, and reaction speed, all play a part in getting a perfect medal. You can play a level over and over again, and you'll never play it the same way twice. The perks are a nice game changer. So much so that you can go back and try to get perfect from those levels that previously gave you a hard time. But the best thing is the game play is in that sweetspot of being challenging but not hard, so although it can get fustrating at times, you'll never get mad enough to want to rage-quit.  Besides that, the music is REALLY good. The option to buy a soundtrack along with the game would have been nice. And apparently the game is long...really long...like 250 levels long, so that's great value.

It is funny how a game can manage to use only 2 mouse buttons throughout its entire gameplay and still able to keep me addicted and entertained. And here it is. One Finger Death Punch.  Don't let the silly title or the simplistic graphics throw you off. The premise of the game is simple, use either the left or right mouse button to attack enemies as they come at you from the left or right. While it sounds simple enough, it can be a real test of mental endurance and finger dexterity when the speed increases and the action goes super frenetic. If you are dedicated enough to try to aim for perfect scores, you are in for a good challenge. This is a game that is absolutely easy to learn yet hard to master.  At its core, it kindda feels like those dance rhythm games. The graphics, while simple looking is brilliantly animated. Even though you're controlling a stick figure, it can be very entertaining to see him do all sorts of crazy martial arts moves like a badass. Occasionally, the game goes all 'Matrix mode' and you can kill enemies slow-mo style, sometimes even a random X-ray mode for that added bone crunching goodness.   The levels varies alot too. Some will have you only bare-fist punching, some will make use of a light-sab...erm...light-sword, others will give you just 1 life and expect you to defend against hordes of dagger throwing foes. The different variations really mix it up to ensure you'll never get bored. Unlock the main game level to open up survival mode, blind survival mode and even a really cute 'No Luca No' mode. I'll leave it up to you to find out what that does.  Music is an eclectic mix of epic sounding orchestral themes, and pulse pounding techno hip hop. The sound quality is rather muffled however but that does not hurt the game very much. You would probably be too busy fending off enemies to focus very much on it anyway. Narration is provided by a stereotypical 'Shifu' voice who does the job admirably.  Overall Rating: 9.0 / 10 They say the best games are the ones that are easy to pick up and play while keeping you entertained. No matter what your skill level, this game will make you feel like a total badass. It distills the best essences of a fighting game and breaks it down to its basics and ultimately delivers a fantastic experience. It certainly doesn't hurt that its pretty cheap too. Definitely a must buy. 2 Thumbs Up!

The DDR of fighting games!! This is the kind of game that defines an ADDICTIVE, SIMPLE, CHALLENGING, ARCADE ACTION!  5 / 5  Like any good addictive arcade experience, simplicity sucks you in right away, then the need to master the game keeps you there for hours. The game has only 2 buttons (but DDR has 4 and look how much skill that takes to master!). Don't be fooled by the simplicity, the game will push your speed, reaction timing, and comprehension to its limits. Button mashing will get you killed and ruin your score. Between 'Perfect' (0 damage), Zero Miss Medals (100% attack success), high-scores to beat through awesome combos/powerups, and as many achievements as a game like this can hold, the game greatly rewards your precision.  Easy to learn, challenging to master. Gratifying arcade style addiction. Get ready for your fingers to get a workout. Well worth full price.

This is the most fun I've ever had with two buttons. Speed, speed, and more speed is the core of the game. Combine that with a kung-fu flick setting with stickmen beating the ever living crap out of eachother, the simplicity of only having to use two buttons, and you have video game gold. One Finger Death Punch is a brawler that plays almost like a violent DDR game where enemies will advance towards you at speeds of no less that 100% (whatever that speed actually is). You can fend them off by using the left and right mouse buttons to attack your foes once they reach a certain distance from you. You can pick up melee weapons if you want to extend your reach, ranged weapons if you just want to say 'Screw it' and reign death on your enemies, and you can use special powers that you unlock over the course of the game such as freezing your enemies, Iron-Man ground-pounding them into submission, and more. For $5, this game will keep you going for a while. Survival modes, levels in the triple digits, and the different ways they push the sinple two-button fighter concept keep the game fresh (though you may only play it for an hour at a time). In short: Go play it. Now.

By all game design logic, this should be the stupidest game ever made, yet it takes its incredibly simple control mechanic and turns it into something awesome! ...provided you have a good sense of timing... ;)   PROS:  Extremely simple to play, fun visuals, good music, difficulty balances itself out as you play so it never feels too hard or too easy.   CONS:  Very repetitive, full-screen mode is a bit aliased instead of looking sharp, your mouse hand may cramp up after a half hour or so, there ARE keyboard controls but they're hidden in a menu which you can only bring up by pausing a game in progress so it's hard to know they're there.

Simple to learn yet difficult to master. This sidescrolling brawler will give you a good time with its fast paced action and simple yet easy to learn fighting mechanic. The music fits well with the games style. Don't let the simple looks and cheap production value keep you from this game. It looks and feels like a cheezy action flick, but it doesnt take more than a single hit to make you feel like a Bruce Lee or Jackie Chan. There is not much else to say, you get variety with something simple as pushing buttons. Oh right, THIS IS NOT A BUTTON MASHER! That is what makes this game addicting. It has the mix of a DDR with Mortal Combat, its less about just pounding the snot of your opponent just to win, but pounding the snot out of your opponent in a much more skilled way. This game has a difficulty curve combined with a skill ceiling that will have you sitting on your ♥♥♥ for hours at a time. Even if you don't have the time to go on a full journey of many stages, they are short enough that you can complete a few in a short amount of time. Don't let that sound like a critisim, the levels seem short, but combine the skill it takes and you have a epic experience made sweetend by the victory. This game has replayability and two modes, leaving you to fight your way through increasing waves and difficult enemies in a variety of game modes. It can get a bit repeative but still a good way to blow off Steam and feel epic. In short, a fun little beat'em with cool action and skill that will keep you entertained.

Pros:  -Freeflowing combat that feels very responsive to every button press.   -Good use of attack strategy in the game can mean the difference between a perfect score or taking a hit.   -Simple but appealing graphical effects and set pieces.  -A soundtrack that enhances the mood of every fight and is awsome to listen to. Everything from fast paced techno to epic sword fighting music.  -No stupid multiple button combinations to memorize. All you need is your two mouse buttons. (Or whatever two keys you pefer)   - Frantic Button mashing is actually frowned upon and can make you lose a fight.   -Lengthy campaign mode that gives a genuine fair challenge. You don't feel like you're being thrown into the thick of it without some practice.   -Nice variety of modes and enemies to change things up and keep the fighting from becoming stale.   -Realistic fighting styles. (With some fantasy elements thrown in.)   -Great replayability of previously beaten levels. It's good to earn a platinum medal, but it's even better to do so and earn a perfect score. (Meaning no missed attacks or hits taken.)   - You could call this a 'lunch-break' type of game as well. It's something you can pick up and play when you need a break from work to recharge.   Cons:   None.   Overall, if you're looking for some quality entertainment that doesn't break the bank. Try One Finger Death Punch. It is one of the most addicting and enjoyable fighting games I've played. You get a generous amount of content for five dollars here and then some. It's a good game that will appeal to hardcore and casual audiences alike.   10/10 would slice open a stick figure's head in glorious fashion again.

One Finger Death Punch is one of those games that takes a very simple mechanic and makes it so compelling that you forget how silly it actually is. 'Everybody was kung-fu fighting' that's the song that got stuck in my head for a long time thanks to this game.  In case you didn't watch any trailers, this game is all about fast paced combat. Not something like Street Fighter or Tekken, instead it's all about two little buttons and whilst that might not sound difficult to master it can be tricky at the very least.  You control a stick figure character that is able to utilize five kung-fu styles & the odd weapon or two. Giving you the ablilty to lay waste to hundreds of enemies in the most spectacular of fashions.  The game features around 250 stages and 3 difficulty levels known as Student, Master & Grand Master. I should also mention that there are quite a variety of enemies that require some rather tricky combo's to get past.  You have to clear each difficulty to unlock the next, but luckily you won't be fighting empty handed for the majority of the time as there are various weapons in this game such as swords, throwing knives, long bows, spears, bombs and death balls. All of which have very limited use of course.  The game also features 21 skills which range from extended striking area to slowing down enemies for a period of time. Skills are activated by achieving the number of kills required for them. Most of these skills are locked when you start but they are unlockable by beating the required stages for the various skills. You can equip up to three on your first play through.  There are also various survival modes that will truly test your skills to see how many kills you can rack up without dying. I really don't want to spoil survivor mode since it was quite a nice surprise when I started it.  This game is something unique, something that I quite enjoyed and really is worth playing for a bit.

One Finger Death Punch is a masterpiece:  -Speed quickly increases after every level you pass -Pretty stellar soundtrack, although only 3 tracks -Multiple level modes and difficulties -Great animations and small 'fatalities' -Awesome Sensei voice actor -Long AF Campaign -Hand-Sweating Tryhard Simulator -Must be Asian to beat   ****9/10****

I picked this up when I was browsing the topmost rated games on steam and this happened to be on top alongside Crypt of the Necrodancer.  So...what is it? It's a rhythm based fighting game where you have control of two buttons which kill whatever enemy is to the right or left of you respecitvely. Enemies come at you in waves and spread apart which make the rhythm rhythmic and you have to carefully time when and how you make your hits to make it through the levels. Difficulty is adaptave, the better you do, the faster things get, the worse you do, the slower things get.  There are power ups which change the gameplay a little. I felt a little slighted here since there is a 'best' combination of power ups to set up before a match. The ones which allow you to survive more hits are much better than the others.  You can beat things down in campaign mode of three difficulties and in a endless mode with increasing difficulty as time progresses.  The execution is fast-paced, simple, and fun. In all...it's a simple game which performs what it tries to do brilliantly and without adding any fat or nusance to the execution.
Very Fun time, you will kung-fu your way with great rhythm. Buy it now.

This is one of the most awesome games to ever exist. Fighting hordes of foes in a ridiculously fun beat em up style game. Easy to learn hard to master, with some of the most epic experiences to be had you'll find anywhere, especially in lightsword rounds. The last survival mode is also hilarious. A casual playthrough of the levels will be engaging, but not ragey, and an achievement go-getter will have a delightfully challenging time. I have only one real complaint: the speed mechanic. Adaptable difficulty is a good concept I've seen add a lot to games, but Speed ups and downs don't happen during the level. They happen in between levels. The result is that earlier levels can be ragingly difficult if approached from later levels, which should never be, and once you understand the system it can be pretty easily juked down to the lowest speed setting. PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE FIX THIS!

This game has absolutely no right to be as fun and amazing as it is.  The game is essentially a glorified QTE- but don't let that turn you away. It is the flashiest, most stylist Kung-Fu themed QTE I have ever had the pleasure to play. The game looks like a button masher but you need to have good reflexes and remember enemy patterns in order to do well. I'm not sure how great the normal campaign is near the end (I've gotten pretty far I think but never finished it), but the survival mode is worth it alone. My rounds have lasted anywhere from five minutes to over half an hour.  I'm just not quite sure how to properly explain this game while doing it justice. The music is fantastic, the game is simple, it's incredibly easy to learn and incredibly difficult to master, has a lot of variety in the campaign, has a fantastic survival mode, and flashy juicy stick figure Kung-Fu gory goodness.  Pick this game up. It's amazing. Just make sure to avoid the F2P Ad-filled Micro-transaction-ridden mobile version. That game broke my heart :(
